title: The Incompatibility of Zero Tolerance with the Tiered Penalty System
body:
I will preface this post with the following: I have never received any penalty whatsoever, and have had an account in good standing since Season 1, playing thousands of both normal and ranked solo queue games.

The penalty system in League of Legends is tiered because the tiered approach gives toxic players an opportunity to reform.  I fully support that, especially given that the majority of players who ever receive a single penalty never receive a second.  The penalty system also has certain zero tolerance words and phrases which will net the player an instant 14 day ban, and I fully agree with that too.  There are some things which simply should not be said, and those things should be penalized severely.

However, the way these two penalties are combined does not make sense.  Using a zero tolerance word or phrase also bumps the penalty tier all the way to the 3rd step, skipping the first two, which means that a single use of a zero tolerance word or phrase followed by even a slight bout of toxicity results in a permanent ban.  While, toxicity should always be avoided, this does not afford the player the opportunity to reform.  He or she may understand that zero tolerance words and phrases are just that, but has not been warned that other parts of his or her chatter are also unacceptable.

I propose a modification to the penalty system, wherein use of a zero tolerance word or phrase results in a 14 day ban but only ticks the penalty tier up one, such that the next penalty on a previously clean account is the 25 day chat restriction, followed by a 14 day ban, and then the permanent ban.  However, a subsequent use of a zero tolerance word or phrase should still result in a permanent ban, regardless of the penalty tier.

Let me add a little clarification to the tiered system. The tiered system is in place to continue escalation of chronically offending players. It is not in place to guarantee that a player receives each and every penalty available. 

As it stands today, every offence is evaluated for severity. After that severity is determined, an appropriate penalty is assigned. If a player has already had that penalty (recently) it will skip to the next.

We do not feel that a chat restriction is sufficient for telling people to kill themselves or attacking people with hate speech (ZT).

I mean obviously you won't be providing those details to the public, that would infringe on the player's privacy. But the player himself should get the chat logs. You know, be explained what he did wrong so he can reform? Otherwise it just looks like an arbitrary, personal and utterly injust measure against a player, inconsistent with any established punishment guidlines and/or rules. What other reason could possibly exist to justify keeping the logs from the "offending" player?

If you got snatched and shoved into prison and then all you would get is "Hey, buddy, a court reviewed your case and your guild was determined and your sentence issued." would you be satisfied, or would you wonder where the whole due process, right to be heard and all that went? Due process in LoL, according to _your_ rules is: a player is toxic -> the player gets reported -> based on the chat logs an automatic system determines guilt and sentence -> the logs are sent to the player so he can reform or contest the punishment with player support.

The ways things are it looks like a major fuck up occured and you guys are covering it up. Just send the dude his logs.

>I mean obviously you won't be providing those details to the public, that would infringe on the player's privacy. But the player himself should get the chat logs. 

I don't think it's something that they can't show the public (or at least that's not the only reason). As those situations are resolved when the person issued the logs give permission to have them shown (such has happened in the past).

>The ways things are it looks like a major fuck up occured and you guys are covering it up.

That's not likely it either, since I've seen situations where the system just completely screws up an bans someone by mistake (even after someone manually reviewed it). They've given apologies and unbanned some players before in the cases I've seen. What would be stopping them from apologizing about a foul-up in the system here if they were willing to do it in other situations?

So my question would be, what kind of behavioral infraction would result in Riot not even explaining the specifics to the player themselves, that would also span across multiple accounts?

I can only think of two possibilities;
- The player did/said something involving someone *else's* personal information. Such as repeated and targeted harassment over several accounts, or doxing someone. Giving chat logs would have Riot transmitting someone else's personal information to the player which I imagine is some sort of legal no-no (even if the player likely had that information saved somewhere, otherwise they couldn't have used it to harass).

\- Something to do with some sort of ongoing legal reason. I can't think of specifics on this one, but the legal world has lots of situations where one or more parties are prohibited from re-transmitting what was said, even to the point where they can't say why the conversation was gagged.

(We call it being PAT: Passive Aggressive Toxic) only gets10 or 25 chat bans. He's gotten a total of 4 penalies in the 3-4 years of playing ad they were never gameplay bans.
This is nice to know actually. As Honor is now linked to both rewards and the punishment system, knowing you only Ban players for extreme uses (like slurs, hate speech and the rainbow of ways to tell someone kill them self) is a relief to people like me who want to make genuine complaints about bad or mean players, but fear being seen as "just as bad" and banned.

I am 100% sure those two first [sample] sentences of his - all alone - were not the cause of a chat restriction.

The system is terrible at detecting insultive metaphors along with passive aggressive attitude, so long these don't inclusive offensive-tagged words. "Wanna land a skill-shot this game?" will never result in chat restriction if it is just that all alone for one simple reason: The system, sadly, sucks ... hard.

I'm sorry but it's still not clear for me. If you get a 2-week ban for ZT and soon after that name-call a fellow player with something "milder" that "should" only be worth a chat-ban, then what happens?
Currently you get permanent suspension as any verbal use punishment after a 14-day suspension for ZT use.

> [{quoted}](name=Riot Tantram,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=xAAcRMo4,comment-id=0007,timestamp=2018-09-20T17:43:56.747+0000)We do not feel that a chat restriction is sufficient for telling people to kill themselves or attacking people with hate speech (ZT).

Fully agree.

That said, what are your thoughts on something like that would normally earn a 10-game chat restriction instead earning a permanent ban on an account that has only had a single 14-day ban for one instance of zero tolerance language, and never had any other punishments?

I don't have strong opinions either way, but I can see the argument that slotting ZT behavior into the penalty system can result in odd cases like this. Is this intended, and part of Riot's strict response to ZT, or is this something you'd consider an edge case where a player might have taken the serious warning to heart, but gotten banned due to other, significantly less egregious behavior?

Do you think there might be a benefit to a system that works as follows?

>**Zero Tolerance:** 14-day ban if the account has not had one, permanent ban if the account HAS had a 14-day ban for any reason. Counts as a one-step escalation on the normal punishment track.
>**Normal Punishments:** 10-game / 25-game / 14-day / Permanent, based on the severity of the behavior.

It seems this might keep the same strict policy on zero-tolerance behavior (or on those using it after significant prior punishments), while also avoiding edge cases where a player who may not know about the zero tolerance gets hit and later receives a minor punishment.

Now, I'm not personally convinced such a system IS necessary (as I feel everyone should know hate speech isn't okay), but I'd be curious to see whether or not this would make a meaningful difference, or whether players who use hate speech are regularly toxic enough otherwise that it wouldn't make a major difference.

This whole thread has been about me kind of so everyone can now use me as an example.

A few nights ago I was playing with a friend duo in bot lane and the other team banned the champion I wanted and I didn't have a back-up who I really wanted to play, so I decided to experiment a little. My friend is a halfway decent Brand player and I'm pretty good at Lissandra so I told him we'd do that. The thematic flavor of Fire and Ice struck me as particularly middle-schoolish, and as my friend and I both share a darker sense of humor I started making jokes more appropriate for middle-school edgelords than functioning adults.

The game went on and this combo worked really well for us so we started cracking jokes in the team chat and then the all chat. Eventually I remembered the FIRE and ICE thing and started up with the dark jokes which quickly spiraled into all kinds of other jokes. I'm not going to name any of them but we covered a pretty broad array of potentially offensive things. At no point did we threaten anyone and at no point did we wish harm on anyone or use material I would consider inexcusable, but quite a bit of it could be considered nsfw.

So. **To my point**. I've been playing since season 2 and never had any form of penalty at any point. I've had every honor ribbon you can have (except that elusive yellow one), and in general I tend to get an honor every game. Opponents used to give me honors when that was thing.  Let's say something I said was flagged as ZT since I know for a fact several people reported me even though I assured them everything I said was meant as comedy. Bam. Instant penalty with threat of permanent ban. Here's my problem with this.

**The judgement system is not perfect.** What one person finds inexcusable and OBVIOUSLY never to be said another could be fine with. For instance, I'm personally fine with 9/11 jokes even though my uncle almost died during that, but people who live on the west coast could find such jokes abhorrent. 
**The judgement system does not have integrity.** I don't know how infractions are judged anymore. Back in the day we had the tribunal and I even used to do it every now and then, but I knew people who said they didn't bother to read the information at all, everyone was guilty. The tribunal was meant to be a filter to send serious cases on up to actual mods, but this always still bothered me.
**The law is vague.** I tried googling the Zero Tolerance policy and wouldn't you know it, I couldn't find it. This is obviously problematic. How are we to know what not to do or say if it is not laid out for us? I know that's going to catch flack but the world is a big place. Did you know that holding up a thumb will get you a taxi in New York and a fight in Asia?

~~I know I’m replying I’m really old threads I’m just deep in it and can’t seem to stop myself from having something to say~~

How do people know when they’ve punched the frequent offender card too many times? 

As someone else already said, what people find offensive -what people find toxic or inexcusable- can be pretty debatable depending on the individual aside from pretty obvious things like racism/homophobia/sexism etc. So what one person sees as clearly hurtful, harmful, rude, or toxic might seem pretty benign to someone else. 

I’ve heard that riot tends to run on the lenient side by also evaluating the frequency of offences before doling out punishment. However imo that leniency is a complete waste because of that differing perspective. A lot of people don’t even realize how awful they really come across as to others. Even if they’re actively rude they might not realize it until either the situation happens to them in reverse or they are actually shown how their interactions look from the outside. This can be seen as a maturity thing too but.. unfortunately some people just aren’t.

If the person who is a repeat offender doesn’t actually realize that they are a repeat offender cause of that “leniency” ~~which to me just sounds like ignoring mild problematic behaviour till they rack up enough bad baby points~~ how are they supposed to fix their behaviour. 

Chat restrictions are good example of that but how about a simple alert once in awhile saying how often you’ve been reported and how much of an opportunity you have left to reform before serious punishment?  Especially concerning the zt thing //and how it leads to some people getting perma bans off of only mild offences becoming routine offences they didn’t even know they were committing.
